conbody.p: When I was a young man – a while back – I clung to the belief that "truth" somehow existed on the other side of my working assumptions, delusions, metaphors, and dogmas. Not so sure now. I find it more practical now to focus on the quality of my life metaphors and not on their deconstruction. The metaphor that "life is a journey" is certainly a high-quality life metaphor and directly relevant to considering your path toward or away from DITA.

section.title: Heroic journeys
section.p: Oh yes – we have been exposed so many instances of heroic journeys that we may assume that they are the default model for setting a new direction.

li.p: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey: Odysseus abandons home and family to join the expedition to Troy. He then abandons the Greek army and eventually all his crew to journey home to Ithaca.
J.R.R. Tolkein's Fellowship of the Ring:
George Lucas' Star Wars: A New Hope: Luke

section.p: Joseph Campbell in Hero with a Thousand Faces suggests that many of these journeys are so similar in narrative shape that they are really variations of one archetypal story.

A common thread in these heroic journeys is that our heroines and heroes cannot turn back or suspend the journey. To describe this sense of total commitment, John Fitzpatrick Kennedy used the metaphor of throwing one's school uniform cap over a high wall. If you didn't scale the wall, you were not admitted back to school.
Is a migration to DITA like one of these heroic journeys? Does it require some heroic level of commitment and detachment from home base?

section.title: Pragmatic journeys
section.p: To my knowledge, no one has penned a heroic journey toward the goal of reducing the number of Customer Support calls, or increasing content reuse to reduce localization costs, or improving customer experience through consistent content organization. Sigh. I do wish that it were so, but what we're paid to do ain't heroic. It's business.

It's good business to be skeptical about anything grandiose with DITA – benefits, costs, disruption, training, consulting, or technologies. It's pragmatic to do some weekend busking before you quit your day job to play music professionally. It's pragmatic to go on some road trips to a region before you sell your house. It's pragmatic to plan some inexpensive day trips before making any commitments to DITA.

li.p: Identify other DITA companies in your area and invite some of their pubs people to a free lunch. Get them talking. Ply them with the appropriate refreshments.
Download, evaluate, and modify collections of open-source DITA sources. See or Open Source DITA Collections.

Talk to reps from or users of competitive solutions to DITA such as MadCap Flare, Paligo, Microsoft Office, Read the Docs, GitHub, or Atlassian Confluence. Transform all the criticisms and concerns into a list of issues that you should research, test, and resolve to your own satisfaction. Get ahead of the issues that someone else will certainly raise if you choose to move ahead with DITA. The Dodgers pitcher Preacher Roe advised young ball players to be diligent in preparing for every game with the quip, "Sometimes you eat the bear and sometimes the bear eats you." You can never be 100% certain how a DITA migration will go, but it certainly helps to talk to people who have walked the same woods you plan to walk or want to scare you away from entering those woods entirely.

Research conference presentations (use cases) about previous DITA migrations – successful and unsuccessful. Reviewing those 20-30 slides on "lessons learned" could easily save you months or years of avoidable pain. I have found that presenters who are mature enough to tell the world what they done right and done wrong in a migration are typically willing to get on ZOOM call with your team do some follow-up. Assume that people are generous and gracious in their wisdom.
Join DITA user groups and user forums.

section.p: Be that pragmatic heroine or hero. Do those day trips before road trips before cross-country relocation.
